moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4: King gambit is always interesting. You think I'd learn by now that d5 is a little easier to play with than the firey continuation of g5.
moves.2... exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ng5 h6: Too aggressive? Maybe. Which color are we talking about?
moves.6. Nxf7 Kxf7 7. Bc4+ d5: Necessary to keep the queen from capturing g4.
moves.8. Bxd5+ Ke8 9. c4: So far I am up a knight for a pawn but at what cost? Seriously, is it even possible to calculate? The f pawn looks like it will drop, I can't castle and none of my pieces are out. Although I am not sure how accurately white plays after this, I think this game could have easily gone either way.
moves.10. Bxg8: The only way to not lose material
moves.11... c5: If I can trade queens I will be okay. Maybe. Neither of us have really developed so predicting how the game will go is very difficult.
moves.12. O-O: ? This invites Qxd4+ trading queens for the f pawn. Although white has counterplay, it does put a damper on his initiative for the knight.
moves.12... f3: The pawn is poisoned. Can you see how? Note, I still have no pieces out.
moves.14... Qxh4+ 15. Kxf3 Bg4+ 16. Ke3 cxd4+: ?? Bxd1 wins quickest although it loses the initiative.
moves.17. Qxd4 Nc6: e5 needs to be defended and Qg3+ does not seem to quite do the trick yet as there is no Rd8.
moves.18. Qd5 Qg3+ 19. Kd2 Rd8:
0-1

...and doesn't that just give you a sickening feeling when you feel you only need to know opening theory?
